organic_results.title: Harvard students in the midst of crisis
organic_results.snippet: A survey of Harvard students was taken in May, 1969, three weeks after the seizure of University Hall and the police bust. Most students at that time did not think the sit-in justified, but a substantial number had changed their opinions during the course of events, moving toward support of the militants. About twenty per cent initially had thought it a good idea to call the police, and this proportion also increased over time. Harvard students place themselves at the left of the political spectrum, far to the left of their senior professors, their …
